fields.value: Home- and community-based growth monitoring to reduce early life growth faltering: an open-label, cluster-randomized controlled trial

dsDescriptionValue.value: Despite the continued high prevalence of faltering growth, height monitoring remains limited in many low- and middle-income countries.  The objective of this study was to test whether providing parents with information on their child's height can improve children's height and developmental outcomes. The results from this trial suggest that growth monitoring has a limited effect on children's height and development, despite improvements in self-reported feeding practices. HBGM had modest positive effects on children with stunted growth. Given its relatively low cost, this intervention may be a cost-effective tool for increasing parental efforts toward reducing children's physical growth deficits.

fields.value: Research Support, Innovations for Poverty Action

value: The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, Volume 106, Issue 4, 1 October 2017, Pages 1070–1077, https://doi.org/10.3945/ajcn.117.157545
Households that had at least one child betewen 6 and 24 months of age at the beginning of the growth monitoring trial in September 2014.

fields.value: The study was designed as an open-label, 3-arm, cluster-randomized control trial. Both treatments involved specific activities directly performed with households. 127 villages in the Chipata District, containing 547 children, were randomized into one of three groups. They were the control group (43 villages, 188 children), a home-based gowth monitoring group (42 villages, 177 children), and community-based growth monitoring group (42 villages, 182 children).
In-person interviews through home-based and community-based growth monitoring
